categories.name: Tie-Ups & Setups
categories.subtitle: Focus is on stance and motion

techniques.name: Collar Tie
techniques.description: A fundamental upper-body control position. Grip behind opponent's neck with one hand while controlling their elbow or wrist with the other.
keyPoints: Cup the back of the neck, pulling the head down
Keep elbow tight to your body for maximum leverage
Use collar tie to set up snaps, drags, and level changes
Stay in good stance - don't lean forward
commonMistakes: Reaching too far and losing balance
Gripping too high on the head

videos.title: Inside Tie & Collar Tie | Wrestling Moves
Wrestling Moves KOLAT.COM Clearing Collar Tie

techniques.name: Inside/Outside Control
techniques.description: Controlling the tie-up battle by fighting for inside or outside wrist and elbow position. Inside ties give you offensive access; outside ties create angles.
keyPoints: Inside position: hands inside opponent's arms, controlling biceps/elbows
Outside position: hands on outside of opponent's arms
Constantly fight to clear opponent's hands and re-establish your ties
Use push-pull motion to create openings
commonMistakes: Being passive and letting opponent control ties
Staying in one position too long

videos.title: Collar Tie💥Rip Defense😉💥
Inside Tie & Collar Tie | Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Head/Shoulder Post
techniques.description: Using your hand on opponent's forehead or shoulder to create distance, control posture, and set up attacks.
keyPoints: Post on forehead or shoulder to control distance
Use the post to redirect opponent's movement
Combine with level changes for takedown entries
Keep arm extended but not locked out
commonMistakes: Pushing straight back instead of redirecting
Leaving arm extended too long

videos.title: Snapping💥1 Hand Post💥#highschoolwrestling #collegewrestling #freestylewrestling #mma #bjj #wrestling
Where To Snap Down

techniques.name: 2 on 1 / Russian Tie
techniques.description: Controlling one of your opponent's arms with both of your hands. One hand grips the wrist, the other controls above the elbow. Creates a dominant angle.
keyPoints: Grip wrist with lead hand, control elbow/tricep with trail hand
Step to the side to create an angle on your opponent
Keep opponent's arm tight to your chest
Use circular motion to off-balance opponent
commonMistakes: Standing square in front of opponent
Loose grip allowing opponent to pull free

videos.title: 2 on 1 Russian Tie Clear & Capture Drill - Cary Kolat Wrestling Drills
High Level Foot Sweep From 2 on 1 - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Underhook
techniques.description: Threading your arm under opponent's arm and securing a grip on their back or shoulder. One of the most powerful neutral position controls.
keyPoints: Drive arm deep under opponent's armpit
Secure grip high on the back or on the far shoulder
Keep your head tight against opponent's chest/chin
Circle toward your underhook side to create angles
commonMistakes: Shallow underhook that gets shucked off
Head too far away allowing opponent to snap you down

videos.title: The Underhook | Wrestling Moves
My D1 College Takedown System

techniques.name: Overhook / Whizzer
techniques.description: Clamping down over opponent's arm from outside, hooking above the elbow. Used both offensively and as a counter to opponent's underhook.
keyPoints: Clamp arm tightly over opponent's bicep/upper arm
Drive hip into opponent to maximize pressure
Use whizzer to counter opponent's underhook or single leg attempts
Can transition to throws and go-behinds
commonMistakes: Whizzer too loose - no pressure
Over-relying on whizzer without attacking

videos.title: The Whizzer | Wrestling Moves
Single Leg Defense Basics - The power of the Whizzer (Overhook)

techniques.name: Circle
techniques.description: Lateral movement in stance to create angles and force reactions from your opponent. Foundation of all good wrestling offense.
keyPoints: Move feet in short, quick steps - never cross feet
Circle in the direction of your setup (toward your strong side)
Use circling to force opponent to adjust, creating openings
Maintain good stance and balance while moving
commonMistakes: Crossing feet while circling
Moving without purpose or setup

videos.title: Shadow Wrestling Drill - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Tricep Circle Double Leg Setup - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Fakes
techniques.description: Using deceptive movements (head fakes, level changes, hand fighting) to draw reactions and create openings for real attacks.
keyPoints: Sell the fake - commit enough to make it believable
Watch for opponent's reaction to determine your real attack
Combine fakes with changes of direction
Use multiple fakes before attacking for real
commonMistakes: Half-hearted fakes that don't draw a reaction
Faking without a plan for the follow-up

videos.title: Leg Attack Fakes Setup - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Elbow Wrist Fake Duck Setups - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Clear & Level Change
techniques.description: Clearing opponent's hands from your head/neck and immediately dropping your level to attack the legs. The gateway to most takedowns.
keyPoints: Strip or swim through opponent's grips quickly
Drop level by bending knees, NOT bending at the waist
Keep back straight and head up during level change
Penetration step drives through opponent's hips
commonMistakes: Bending at waist instead of knees
Telegraphing the level change with eyes

videos.title: Split Step Level Change - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Penetration Step Power Leg - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Snapdown
techniques.description: A sharp downward pull on opponent's head/neck to break their posture and create a front headlock or go-behind opportunity.
keyPoints: Sharp, quick pull downward - not a slow drag
Pull with both hands (collar tie + wrist control)
Step back as you snap to create space
Immediately follow up: front headlock, go behind, or re-attack
commonMistakes: Snapping without moving your feet
Not following up after the snap

videos.title: Snap Down | Wrestling Moves
Using Head Position to Set the Snap - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Arm Drag
techniques.description: Pulling opponent's arm across their body to create an angle for a go-behind or takedown. Quick, explosive upper body technique.
keyPoints: Grip opponent's wrist and tricep
Pull arm across while stepping to the side
Your trail hand reaches for opponent's far hip or back
Stay low and attack immediately after the drag
commonMistakes: Dragging without moving your feet
Standing too tall during the drag

videos.title: Arm Drag to Single Leg Snag - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
The Arm Drag | Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Duck Under
techniques.description: Ducking underneath opponent's arm to get behind them. Works from collar tie or underhook position.
keyPoints: Pop opponent's elbow up to create space
Duck your head under their arm while stepping across
Keep moving through - don't stop under their arm
Secure back control immediately (lock hands around waist)
commonMistakes: Ducking without popping the arm up first
Stopping halfway and getting re-faced

videos.title: Duck Under Basics - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Duck Under | Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Hand/Wrist Control
techniques.description: Controlling opponent's wrists to limit their offense and set up your own attacks. Fundamental skill for all positions.
keyPoints: Grip wrist firmly with thumb on back of hand
Use wrist control to redirect opponent's attacks
Clear wrists quickly when on bottom
Control both wrists to shut down opponent's offense
commonMistakes: Gripping too tightly and fatiguing forearms
Holding wrists without attacking

videos.title: Inside Tie & Collar Tie | Wrestling Moves
Wrist Control Clearing Ties - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Elbow Control
techniques.description: Controlling opponent's elbow to limit arm movement and set up attacks. Elbow control gives you leverage over their entire arm.
keyPoints: Cup opponent's elbow from underneath
Drive elbow up or across to create openings
Use elbow control to set up dumps and duck unders
Maintain inside position for best control
commonMistakes: Grabbing too high on the arm
Not using the control to attack

videos.title: Inside Tie & Collar Tie | Wrestling Moves
Wrist Control Clearing Ties - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Breaking Locks
techniques.description: Techniques for breaking apart an opponent's locked hands, critical for escaping body locks, cradles, and riding holds.
keyPoints: Attack the weakest point - usually the fingers or wrist
Use two hands against one to peel grips
Wrist roll: rotate opponent's wrist to break lock
Create space first, then attack the lock
commonMistakes: Trying to pull straight apart instead of peeling
Panicking instead of working methodically

videos.title: Inside Tie & Collar Tie | Wrestling Moves
Wrist Control Clearing Ties - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Double Leg
techniques.description: The most fundamental wrestling takedown. Level change and drive through both of opponent's legs, lifting or driving them to the mat.
keyPoints: Clear ties and change level (bend knees, not waist)
Penetration step: lead knee hits the mat between opponent's feet
Head on the outside, arms wrap both legs at the knees
Drive through with your legs - head up, back straight
Finish by lifting, turning the corner, or running the pipe
commonMistakes: Shooting from too far away
Head down during the shot
Not driving through on the finish

videos.title: Double Leg Take Down Basics
Double Leg Head Drive - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Single Leg
techniques.description: Attack one of opponent's legs. Versatile takedown with many setups and finishes.
keyPoints: Level change and drive into opponent's lead leg
Head on the inside (ear against their ribs)
Grip behind the knee and pull leg tight to your chest
Finish options: run the pipe, trip, sweep, dump, or lift
commonMistakes: Head on the outside (exposes back)
Standing up straight with the leg instead of staying in stance

videos.title: Arm Drag to Single Leg Snag - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Sweep Single Penetration Step - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Snatch Single
techniques.description: A quick, explosive grab of opponent's lead leg without a full penetration step. Works from collar tie or hand fighting.
keyPoints: Snap opponent's head down to get them to post their weight forward
Quick reach - grab behind the knee in one motion
Immediately elevate the leg and drive forward
Transition to standard single leg finishes
commonMistakes: Reaching without a setup
Bending over at the waist to grab

videos.title: Arm Drag to Single Leg Snag - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Sweep Single Takedown - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: High Crotch
techniques.description: A takedown that targets the upper thigh/hip area. Versatile attack that can finish as a single, double, or lift.
keyPoints: Level change with penetration step to the outside
Head on the inside, arm wraps high around the thigh
Drive into opponent's hip with your shoulder
Finish by turning the corner, lifting, or transitioning to a double
commonMistakes: Staying square instead of angling off
Not driving hips in on the finish

videos.title: High Crotch Fundamentals
High Crotch Take Down Basics

techniques.name: Go Behind
techniques.description: Getting behind your opponent from neutral position. Scored as a takedown. Can be achieved from arm drags, duck unders, or scrambles.
keyPoints: Create an angle first (arm drag, duck under, or snap)
Secure a grip around opponent's waist or on their hips
Keep chest tight to their back - no space
Stay on your toes, ready to follow their movement
commonMistakes: Reaching around without creating an angle first
Loose grip allowing opponent to turn in

videos.title: The Front Headlock | Wrestling Moves
Go Behind Details

techniques.name: Slide By / Throw By
techniques.description: Using opponent's forward pressure against them by redirecting and sliding past to get behind.
keyPoints: When opponent pushes into you, redirect their energy to the side
Pull their arm/head past you while stepping to the side
Stay low and circle behind as they go past
Secure waist control immediately
commonMistakes: Trying to slide by when opponent is pulling back
Not staying low enough

videos.title: SLIDE BY | Wrestling Moves
The EASIEST Wrestling Takedown - Jax Forrest

techniques.name: Ankle Pick
techniques.description: A quick, short-range takedown where you grab opponent's ankle while controlling their head or arm. Low risk, high reward.
keyPoints: Control opponent's head or collar tie with one hand
Snap head down while reaching for the far or near ankle
Pull ankle toward you while driving head/shoulder down
Stay in good position to follow up
commonMistakes: Reaching for the ankle without snapping head first
Going to both knees

videos.title: Iron Faith Wrestling Breakdown #17| Mike Ross Ankle Pick To Double Leg
Ankle Pick | Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Knee Pick
techniques.description: Similar to ankle pick but targeting the knee. Effective from tie-ups and after a misdirection fake.
keyPoints: Control head and create downward pressure
Reach behind opponent's knee from outside
Pull knee toward you while driving with your head/shoulder
Follow through to a finish - don't stop after the pick
commonMistakes: Grabbing on top of the knee instead of behind it
Not controlling the head

videos.title: Russian 2 on 1 Low Level Knee Pick With Foot Block
Underhook Knee Pick

techniques.name: Body Lock Throws
techniques.description: Locking hands around opponent's torso and using leverage to throw or trip them to the mat. Includes hip toss, headlock, and dump variations.
keyPoints: Secure a tight lock around opponent's body (Gable grip preferred)
Drive hips in close - chest to chest
Use hip pop + rotation for throws
Stay heavy on top after the throw
commonMistakes: Loose grip allowing opponent to escape
Throwing without hip contact

videos.title: Zhumashbek Puts on a Bodylock Clinic @ Bill Farrell (Breakdown) (Excerpt)
Wrestling Offense: Body Lock Throw

techniques.name: Hip Toss
techniques.description: A throw where you turn into your opponent, load them onto your hip, and rotate them over to the mat.
keyPoints: Secure underhook or bodylock position
Turn your back into opponent's chest, load onto your hip
Pull with your arms while popping your hip
Follow through to maintain top position
commonMistakes: Not getting hip deep enough
Throwing without pulling with the arms

videos.title: Wrestling Moves KOLAT.COM Single Leg to Hip Toss
Single To Hip Toss

techniques.name: Headlock Throw
techniques.description: Wrapping opponent's head and throwing them over your hip. High-risk, high-reward technique.
keyPoints: Wrap arm around opponent's head with a tight grip
MUST include their arm to avoid an illegal headlock
Pop hip and throw in one explosive motion
Land on top - never throw without following through
commonMistakes: Not including the arm (illegal!)
Falling to your back on the throw

videos.title: The Front Headlock | Wrestling Moves
Tanner Cook's High-Reward Front Headlock Offense

techniques.name: Fireman's Carry
techniques.description: Drop to one knee, thread your arm between opponent's legs, and roll them over your shoulders to the mat. Inside and outside variations.
keyPoints: Control opponent's arm (wrist or elbow)
Level change - drop to lead knee
Thread opposite arm between their legs
Pull arm and lift with your legs, rolling opponent across your back
commonMistakes: Not controlling the arm through the throw
Getting stuck on your knees

videos.title: Fireman's Carry | Wrestling Moves
Takedown Outside Step Arm Drag to fireman's Carry

techniques.name: Front Headlock
techniques.description: Controlling opponent's head and arm from the front when they shoot or get snapped down. A powerful position with many attack options.
keyPoints: Lock around opponent's head and far arm (Gable grip)
Keep your weight heavy on their back - chest pressure
Hips back, sprawled legs for base
Attack from here: go behind, chokes, throws
commonMistakes: Being too upright - need weight on them
Holding without attacking

videos.title: The Front Headlock | Wrestling Moves
Front Headlock Proper Position - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Snap & Elbow Pass
techniques.description: From a front headlock, snap opponent down while passing their elbow to the other side to go behind.
keyPoints: Secure front headlock position
Snap head down sharply to get them reaching for the mat
Pass their elbow across while circling behind
Secure waist control for the go-behind
commonMistakes: Not snapping hard enough to create movement
Losing head control during the pass

videos.title: Elbow Snap Setup - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Inside Elbow Throw By - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Shuck
techniques.description: From a front headlock or collar tie, throwing opponent past you by redirecting their momentum to the side.
keyPoints: Use opponent's forward pressure against them
Pull head/arm to the side while stepping out of the way
Circle behind as opponent goes past
Can be done from front headlock, collar tie, or any tie-up
commonMistakes: Trying to shuck without opponent having forward pressure
Not circling behind quickly enough

videos.title: Front Headlock Shuck - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Clearing A Front Headlock - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Whip Over
techniques.description: From a front headlock, using a whipping motion to roll opponent over to their back. Can also be done from an overhook.
keyPoints: Secure tight front headlock or overhook
Create rotation by pulling their head/arm down and across
Whip your body over the top in a circular motion
Follow through to secure a pin or near-fall position
commonMistakes: Not having a tight enough grip
Whipping without hip involvement

videos.title: Clearing A Front Headlock - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Front Headlock Shuck - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Cement Job / Mixer
techniques.description: From a front headlock, driving opponent's head into the mat while circling to expose their back. Also called a cement mixer.
keyPoints: Tight front headlock with Gable grip
Drive opponent's head toward the mat
Circle toward their head while keeping pressure
Roll them through to expose their back for near-fall
commonMistakes: Losing the grip during the roll
Not keeping enough pressure on the head

videos.title: Cement⚡️Job⚡️Elevator⤵️ #freestylewrestling #collegewrestling #wrestling #highschoolwrestling #mma
Front Headlock to Cement Job - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Sprawl Go-Behind
techniques.description: Defending a shot with a sprawl, then immediately transitioning to get behind the opponent for a takedown.
keyPoints: Sprawl: shoot hips back, chest heavy on opponent's back
As opponent is stuffed, circle to the side
Grab around their waist or lock onto a hip
Pull them toward you while getting your hips behind theirs
commonMistakes: Sprawling but not attacking from the position
Getting back to your feet without following up

videos.title: Best Sprawl Position To Stop Leg Attack - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Single Sprawl Go Behind

techniques.name: Body Lock Counter
techniques.description: Upgrading from tie-ups to a body lock and using it to score takedowns via trips, throws, and lifts.
keyPoints: From underhook, reach around to lock hands behind opponent's back
Gable grip preferred for strength
Pop hips in for trips and throws
Keep pressure chest-to-chest
commonMistakes: Locking hands too low
Not using hip pressure

videos.title: Zhumashbek Puts on a Bodylock Clinic @ Bill Farrell (Breakdown) (Excerpt)
Wrestling Offense: Body Lock Throw

techniques.name: Crotch Lock
techniques.description: A counter-wrestling technique where you secure a grip around opponent's leg at the crotch level from a scramble situation.
keyPoints: Thread arm through opponent's legs from a scramble position
Lock hands together around the upper thigh
Use leverage to turn opponent or return them to the mat
Keep tight and follow through to a finish
commonMistakes: Loose lock that opponent can slip out of
Not following through to a finish

videos.title: Crotch Lift KOLAT.COM Wrestling Techniques Moves Instruction
Crotch Lift + Pickup - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Scramble / Dogfight
techniques.description: Dynamic exchanges where both wrestlers are fighting for position. Dogfight is a specific scramble where both wrestlers are on their knees battling for underhooks.
keyPoints: Stay heavy and keep moving - never stop in a scramble
Fight for inside position and underhooks
In dogfight: get head up and drive into opponent
Always look to get behind or on top
commonMistakes: Freezing during a scramble
Giving up position instead of fighting through

videos.title: Dog Fight / Coyote Guard Instructional | Gi & Nogi Underhook Sweep System
60 Dog Fight Under-Hook Half Guard Techniques In Just 18 Minutes by Jason Scully - BJJ Grappling
videos.channel: Jiu Jitsu In Minutes by Jason Scully

techniques.name: Tight Waist
techniques.description: Fundamental top control. One arm wraps tight around opponent's waist. The base position for most breakdowns and turns.
keyPoints: Lock arm tight around opponent's waist, elbow in their hip
Drive chest pressure into their back
Other hand controls wrist, ankle, or far arm
Use hip pressure to flatten them out
commonMistakes: Arm too loose around waist
Weight too high on opponent's back

videos.title: Wrestling Moves KOLAT.COM Wrestling Chop & Tight Waist
Defending Tight Waist:  Hipping Down Against Tight Waist Anchor Opponent to Mat

techniques.name: Chop / Cross Wrist
techniques.description: A breakdown where you chop opponent's elbow while pulling their far wrist across. Flattens them to the mat for turns.
keyPoints: One hand chops inside of opponent's near elbow
Other hand reaches under to grab far wrist (cross-wrist)
Pull wrist across while driving forward with chest
Transition to half nelson, arm bar, or cradle
commonMistakes: Not chopping the elbow sharply enough
Losing chest pressure during the reach

videos.title: Wrestling Moves KOLAT.COM Wrestling Chop & Tight Waist
Top Wrestling:  Cross Wrist Threading the Needle Tilt

techniques.name: Spiral Ride
techniques.description: A dynamic riding technique where you control opponent's wrist and ankle on the same side, spiraling them to the mat.
keyPoints: Grab near wrist and far ankle
Drive opponent's wrist toward the mat in a spiral motion
Pull ankle toward you to take away their base
Follow through to a breakdown or turn
commonMistakes: Reaching for the ankle and losing top pressure
Not spiraling - just pulling straight

videos.title: Spiral Breakdown Proper Drive
Tricep Circle Double Leg Setup - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Ankle Breakdown
techniques.description: From top position, pulling opponent's ankle out to flatten them to the mat and remove their base.
keyPoints: Reach back and hook opponent's far ankle
Pull ankle toward you while driving forward with upper body
Opponent loses their base and flattens out
Transition to turns or further riding
commonMistakes: Reaching too far back and losing position
Not driving forward while pulling the ankle

videos.title: 2 on 1 Near Ankle - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Collar Tie Slip Ankle Pick - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Mat Return
techniques.description: Returning an opponent who is standing or getting up back down to the mat. Chair sit and waist lift are primary methods.
keyPoints: Chair sit: lock waist and sit back, pulling opponent into your lap
Waist lift: lock waist tight and lift/rotate them back down
Keep hands locked and pressure constant
Follow up immediately with a ride or turn
commonMistakes: Loose hand lock that opponent breaks
Letting opponent get fully to their feet before acting

videos.title: Mat Return | Wrestling Moves
Front Trip Mat Return

techniques.name: Half Nelson
techniques.description: The most fundamental pinning combination. Thread arm under opponent's arm and behind their neck, driving them to their back.
keyPoints: From top/side position, thread arm under opponent's near arm
Hand goes behind their neck - drive with palm
Keep chest heavy on their back
Walk toward their head to turn them to their back
commonMistakes: Arm not deep enough under opponent's arm
Not keeping chest pressure

videos.title: Half Nelson
Arm Bar to Half Nelson - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Power Half Nelson
techniques.description: An enhanced half nelson where you add a wrist control for extra leverage and power to turn your opponent.
keyPoints: Standard half nelson with one arm
Other hand grabs opponent's far wrist and pulls it across
Combined leverage makes the turn much more powerful
Drive toward opponent's head to complete the turn
commonMistakes: Losing the wrist control during the turn
Not driving with the hips

videos.title: Arm Bar to Half Nelson - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Half Nelson

techniques.name: Three Quarter Nelson
techniques.description: Threading both arms through for a deeper nelson. Very powerful turning combination when you can secure it.
keyPoints: Thread both arms under opponent's arms and behind the neck
Lock hands together behind opponent's head
Drive forward and walk toward their head
Extremely powerful turn - hard to resist
commonMistakes: Leaving too much space - need to stay chest-to-chest
Losing the lock

videos.title: Arm Bar to Half Nelson - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
The Crossface Pancake Is The Perfect 2nd Move

techniques.name: Near Side Cradle
techniques.description: Locking opponent's head and near-side knee together. A high-percentage pinning combination from top position.
keyPoints: From tight waist, drive opponent's head down
Reach over the neck while hooking the near knee
Lock hands together (S-grip or Gable grip)
Squeeze elbows together and drive to your hip for the pin
commonMistakes: Lock is too loose
Not squeezing elbows together

videos.title: This New Cradle Variation Is a Guaranteed Pin
Near Side Cradle

techniques.name: Far Side Cradle
techniques.description: Locking opponent's head and far-side knee together. Requires reaching across but can be very effective.
keyPoints: From top position, reach across to hook opponent's far knee
Other arm goes around the head
Lock hands and roll to your hip
Pull knees-to-head to tighten the cradle
commonMistakes: Not reaching deep enough for the far knee
Rolling the wrong direction

videos.title: This New Cradle Variation Is a Guaranteed Pin
The Cradle | Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Arm Bar / Wing
techniques.description: Controlling opponent's arm and using leverage to turn them. Arm bar traps the arm against your body; wing variation hooks under.
keyPoints: Trap opponent's arm against your body with both hands
Drive forward into them to break them down
Walk toward their head to turn them to their back
Keep constant pressure - don't let them pull the arm free
commonMistakes: Arm slipping out due to loose grip
Not driving with your legs

videos.title: Arm Bar Tilt
Arm Bar Turn - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Turk
techniques.description: A leg-riding turn where you hook opponent's leg with your leg and use it to turn them to their back.
keyPoints: From top position, thread your leg between opponent's legs
Hook their far leg with your foot/ankle
Use leg hook combined with upper body control to turn
Maintain the hook throughout the turn
commonMistakes: Losing the leg hook during the turn
Not having upper body control

videos.title: KOLAT.COM Wrestling Techniques: Drew Headlee Turk to Low Leg Cradle
KOLAT.COM Wrestling Techniques: Drew Headlee Turk & Low Leg Cradle Cross Ankle to Turk

categories.name: Defense I
categories.subtitle: From standing / on your feet - HEAD HANDS HIPS

techniques.name: Defending Double Leg
techniques.description: Techniques for stopping an opponent's double leg takedown attempt. Key phrase: HEAD HANDS HIPS.
keyPoints: Sprawl: shoot hips back and down, chest heavy on opponent
Crossface with your forearm across their face
Whizzer (overhook) on the arm they're reaching with
Circle away from the attack to create an angle
commonMistakes: Not reacting quickly enough
Sprawling but staying flat instead of hip-heavy

videos.title: Best Sprawl Position To Stop Leg Attack - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Wrestling Sprawl Secrets by John Smith

techniques.name: Defending Single Leg
techniques.description: Stopping an opponent's single leg attack. Focus on controlling their head and freeing your leg.
keyPoints: Whizzer immediately on the same side as the attacked leg
Crossface to push their head down and away
Hop on your free leg to maintain balance
Kick your leg free or limp leg out of their grip
commonMistakes: Hopping backward instead of circling
Reaching down for your own leg

videos.title: Best Sprawl Position To Stop Leg Attack - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Wrestling Sprawl Secrets by John Smith

techniques.name: Defending High Crotch
techniques.description: Defending the high crotch attack by controlling the head and preventing the lift.
keyPoints: Cross-face to control opponent's head position
Overhook/whizzer on the attacking arm
Drive your hips down to prevent the lift
Circle away from the attack
commonMistakes: Letting opponent get under your hips
Leaning too far forward

videos.title: Best Sprawl Position To Stop Leg Attack - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Wrestling Sprawl Secrets by John Smith

categories.name: Defense II
categories.subtitle: Bottom basics - HEAD UP = GET UP

techniques.name: Solid Base
techniques.description: The foundation of bottom wrestling. Building and maintaining a strong base position to resist breakdowns.
keyPoints: Hands and knees position with wide base
Elbows in, head up
Fill your hands (grab opponent's wrists on your waist)
Fight pressure - don't let them flatten you
commonMistakes: Head down (HEAD UP = GET UP)
Elbows out, exposing yourself to breakdowns

videos.title: Why 99% of Beginners Get Stuck on Bottom (And How to Escape)
Defending the Tight Waist Ride to Stand-Up - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Clearing Wrists
techniques.description: On bottom, stripping opponent's hand control so you can execute your escapes cleanly.
keyPoints: Grab opponent's hands/wrists on your waist
Peel one hand at a time - two hands vs one
Clear to the outside and attack immediately
Don't just clear - have your next move ready
commonMistakes: Trying to clear both hands at once
Clearing without following up with an escape

videos.title: Why 99% of Beginners Get Stuck on Bottom (And How to Escape)
Defending the Tight Waist Ride to Stand-Up - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Defending Half Nelson
techniques.description: Preventing opponent from turning you with a half nelson from top position.
keyPoints: Keep elbow tight to your side to block the arm thread
Post your hand on the mat to create a base
Turn into the nelson - don't turn away
Grab opponent's wrist and fight the arm back out
commonMistakes: Elbows out allowing easy arm thread
Turning away from the nelson (helps them turn you)

videos.title: Arm Bar to Half Nelson - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves
Half Nelson

techniques.name: Sit Out & Knee Slide
techniques.description: From bottom, sit through by kicking legs out and turning to face opponent. Knee slide variation uses knee movement to initiate.
keyPoints: Clear opponent's hands off your waist
Kick your legs through and sit to your hip
Turn toward opponent immediately - don't stay seated
Come up facing your opponent, ready to attack
commonMistakes: Sitting out without clearing hands first
Sitting and staying instead of turning back in

videos.title: Why 99% of Beginners Get Stuck on Bottom (And How to Escape)
Push Back Sit to Switch - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Switch
techniques.description: From bottom, reversing position by sitting to your hip, reaching back, and switching to behind your opponent.
keyPoints: Sit to your hip and clear the near-side hand
Reach back between opponent's legs or over their thigh
Rotate your hips 180 degrees
End up behind opponent with control
commonMistakes: Not sitting to the hip first
Reaching back without clearing the hand

videos.title: Push Back Sit💥Switch💥🤩
Push Back Sit to Switch - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Stand Up
techniques.description: The most fundamental bottom escape. Clear hands, get to your feet, and peel away. HEAD UP = GET UP.
keyPoints: Fill your hands - grab opponent's hands on your waist
Pop up to your feet in one explosive motion
Keep your back straight, head up
Clear one hand at a time and turn to face opponent
commonMistakes: Head down while standing (get broken back down)
Standing without clearing hands first

videos.title: Why 99% of Beginners Get Stuck on Bottom (And How to Escape)
How To Get Off Bottom (works 99% of the time)

techniques.name: Tripod / Quadpod
techniques.description: Heavy base positions on bottom to resist being broken down. Quadpod (all fours) and tripod (three points) give maximum stability.
keyPoints: Quadpod: hands and feet (not knees) on the mat for maximum height
Tripod: three points of contact, heavy hips
Use as a strong starting position before executing an escape
Makes it very difficult for opponent to break you down
commonMistakes: Staying in the position too long without attacking
Not keeping hips heavy

videos.title: Tripod Stand Up (BEST ESCAPE)
Quad Pod | Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Sit Out Drill
techniques.description: Repetitive practice of the sit out escape to build muscle memory. Can be done solo or with a partner.
keyPoints: Start in referee's position on bottom
Practice sit out motion in rapid succession
Focus on speed and hip rotation
Partner provides light resistance, increasing over time
commonMistakes: Going through the motions without intensity
Not turning back to face partner

videos.title: Why 99% of Beginners Get Stuck on Bottom (And How to Escape)
Push Back Sit to Switch - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Switch Drill
techniques.description: Repetitive practice of the switch escape to build muscle memory.
keyPoints: Start in referee's position
Execute switch with full hip rotation
Reset and repeat rapidly
Progress from no resistance to live
commonMistakes: Incomplete hip rotation
Not resetting to proper position

videos.title: Why 99% of Beginners Get Stuck on Bottom (And How to Escape)
Push Back Sit to Switch - Cary Kolat Wrestling Moves

techniques.name: Stand Up Drill
techniques.description: Repetitive practice of the stand up escape to build speed and timing.
keyPoints: Start in referee's position
Explosive stand up - clear hands and face opponent
Reset and repeat
Partner provides increasing resistance
commonMistakes: Standing slowly instead of explosively
Head dropping during the stand up

videos.title: Why 99% of Beginners Get Stuck on Bottom (And How to Escape)
